Situation1: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I sat at my desk, Bible open, notes scattered, heart set on crafting a sermon that would help my congregation navigate the moral gray areas of their lives. Sunday was only two days away, and I felt the weight of their expectations—guidance, clarity, hope. Just as I found the right passage, my phone buzzed. It was a message from the volunteer coordinator at the community kitchen where I serve every Saturday. The message was urgent: new procedures had to be implemented immediately, no exceptions, or the kitchen would be shut down. The guidelines, though well-intentioned, clashed with the message I was preparing—one about compassion and flexibility in the face of rigid rules. As a pastor, I wanted to teach understanding and grace; as a volunteer, I was expected to enforce strict compliance. My mind spun with the tension between what I believed and what I was being asked to do. I stared at my sermon notes, then at the coordinator’s message, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which voice to follow.
